# Motivation

To practice R programming through hands-on exercises, as it is the best way to enhance your programming skills.

In this tutorial, we will solve problems from Section 25.2.5 of the famous **R 4 Data Science by Hadley Wickham et al.** Let's get started!

# Loading Required Libraries

In this section, we will load `tidyverse`package.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
# Libraries
library(tidyverse)
```
:::

### Putting it Together


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
# Write a function that combines the above three functions into one function
calc_mean_and_percent <- function(data, vars, digits) {
  data |>
    reframe(
      across(
        {{ vars }},
        list(
          mean = \(x) mean(is.na(x)),
          prop = \(x) x / sum(x, na.rm = TRUE),
          pct  = \(x) x / sum(x, na.rm = TRUE) * 100
        ),
        .names = "{.fn}_{.col}"
      )
    ) |>
    mutate(across(where(is.numeric), \(x) round(x, {{ digits }})))
}

# Test the function:
calc_mean_and_percent(
  data,
  vars = c(x, y, z),
  digits = 2
) |>
	knitr::kable(align = "c")
```

2)  In the second variant of rescale01(), infinite values are left unchanged. Can you rewrite rescale01() so that -Inf is mapped to 0, and Inf is mapped to 1?


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
# Data frame
df <- tibble(
  a = rnorm(5),
  b = rnorm(5),
  c = rnorm(5),
  d = rnorm(5),
)

# Modify rescale01
rescale01 <- function(x) {
  rng <- range(x, na.rm = TRUE, finite = TRUE)
  value <- (x - rng[1]) / (rng[2] - rng[1])
  value <- case_when(
    value == Inf ~ 1,
    value == -Inf ~ 0,
    TRUE ~ round(value, 3)
  )
  value
}

mutate(df, across(a:d, \(x) rescale01(x)))
```

3)  Given a vector of birthdates, write a function to compute the age in years.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
# Create a sample dataset
df <-
  tibble(
    name = c("Mawan", "Garang", "Ayen", "Alier"),
    birth_date = c("2020-11-23", "1981-05-24", "2003-02-18", "N/A")
  )

# Write function
calculate_birth_years <- function(df, b_date, ref_date = today()) {
  df |>
    mutate(
      years_of_birth = if_else(is.na({{ b_date }}), NA_real_,
        round(interval(ymd({{ b_date }}), ref_date) / years(1), 2)
      )
    )
}

# Let's test our new function
calculate_birth_years(df, birth_date)
```

4)  Write your own functions to compute the variance and skewness of a numeric vector. You can look up the definitions on Wikipedia or elsewhere.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
# Create a dummy data frame
a <- rnorm(n = 10000, mean = 450, sd = 150)

hist(a)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](tutorial-02_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-12-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
# Write a function for calculating a variance and skewness of a numeric vector

calculate_variance <- function(x) {
  n <- length(x)

  if (n > 1) {
    variance <- sum((x - mean(x, na.rm = TRUE))^2) / (n - 1)
  } else {
    NA_real_
  }
  variance
}

# Function to calculate the skewness of a numeric vector
calculate_skewness <- function(x) {
  n <- length(x)

  if (n > 2) {
    variance <- calculate_variance(x)
    skewness <- sum((x - mean(x, na.rm = TRUE))^3) / (n * variance^(3 / 2))
  } else {
    return(NA_real_)
  }
  round(skewness, 5)
}


# Kurtosis
calculate_kurtosis <- function(x) {
  # Calculate sample mean
  avg <- mean(x)

  # Calculate sample kurtosis
  n <- length(x)
  kurtosis <- (sum((x - avg)^4) / n) / ((sum((x - avg)^2) / n)^2) - 3

  kurtosis
}

calculate_kurtosis(a)
```
